content.raw:
The processes are not being properly terminated when the GUI is closed:

1.  `ign gazebo -v 4 -f examples/worlds/empty.sdf`
1.  Close the window
1. This is printed: `Library error: Problem running [gazebo]() from libignition-gazebo2-ign.so.` and the process is still alive.

content.raw:
The default world is not working:

1. Start without a world file: `ign gazebo -v 4`
1. It prints `[Dbg] [SimulationRunner.cc:541] Loaded system [ignition::gazebo::systems::SceneBroadcaster] for entity [1]`, but it doesn't print `[Msg] Serving scene information on [/world/default/scene/info]`
1. It hangs printing this repeatedly: `[GUI] [Dbg] [Scene3D.cc:285] Waiting for service /world/default/scene/info`
content.html:

  3. It hangs printing this repeatedly: [GUI] [Dbg] [Scene3D.cc:285] Waiting for service /world/default/scene/info

content.raw:
`OptionParser` supports positional arguments, so the implementation is straight forward. This worked for me:

~~~
diff -r 92d094429e5a src/cmd/cmdgazebo.rb.in                                    
--- a/src/cmd/cmdgazebo.rb.in   Mon Apr 29 16:47:28 2019 -0700                   
+++ b/src/cmd/cmdgazebo.rb.in   Tue Apr 30 12:53:00 2019 -0700 
@@ -221,6 +219,11 @@
 
     opt_parser.parse!(args)
 
+    filename = args.pop
+    if filename and filename != 'gazebo'
+      options['file'] = filename
+    end
+
     options['command'] = args[0]
 
     options
~~~


I think the bigger question is whether we want to do it. After several months using ign-gazebo, I vote for the change. I forget to add `-f` way too often, and opening a file by passing it directly is more in line with how other applications work.
content.html:
OptionParser supports positional arguments, so the implementation is straight forward. This worked for me:

diff -r 92d094429e5a src/cmd/cmdgazebo.rb.in                                    
--- a/src/cmd/cmdgazebo.rb.in   Mon Apr 29 16:47:28 2019 -0700                   
+++ b/src/cmd/cmdgazebo.rb.in   Tue Apr 30 12:53:00 2019 -0700 
@@ -221,6 +219,11 @@

     opt_parser.parse!(args)

+    filename = args.pop
+    if filename and filename != 'gazebo'
+      options['file'] = filename
+    end
+
     options['command'] = args[0]

     options

I think the bigger question is whether we want to do it. After several months using ign-gazebo, I vote for the change. I forget to add -f way too often, and opening a file by passing it directly is more in line with how other applications work.

content.raw: I also think it's harmless to also support the current `-f` and `--file` at the same time.
content.html: I also think it's harmless to also support the current -f and --file at the same time.

content.html: See pull request #298 with this and other smaller suggestions

content.raw:
I appreciate the effort, but I did say "please don't make any changes like this until after Blueprint. Ideally feature creep is now now feature retreat.".

The intent is to limit the amount of work we are doing on core features because there is a major subt integration effort looming over our shoulders.

I'll take a look at your pull request soon.
content.html:
I appreciate the effort, but I did say "please don't make any changes like this until after Blueprint. Ideally feature creep is now now feature retreat.".

The intent is to limit the amount of work we are doing on core features because there is a major subt integration effort looming over our shoulders.

I'll take a look at your pull request soon.

content.raw:
May I suggest using the first positional argument as the sdf file instead of `-f`, i.e `ign gazebo [options] FILE`. I think people that have used classic Gazebo expect this behavior and IMHO, having the input file as the positional argument is the most popular convention. 

If we choose not to go this route, at the very least, if users do `ign gazebo file.sdf`, we should print out a warning saying "did you mean ign gazebo -f file.sdf?" There is an issue related to this in #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/issues/12/dont-fail-silently-when-trying-to-load-a
content.html:
May I suggest using the first positional argument as the sdf file instead of -f, i.e ign gazebo [options] FILE. I think people that have used classic Gazebo expect this behavior and IMHO, having the input file as the positional argument is the most popular convention.

If we choose not to go this route, at the very least, if users do ign gazebo file.sdf, we should print out a warning saying "did you mean ign gazebo -f file.sdf?" There is an issue related to this in #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/issues/12/dont-fail-silently-when-trying-to-load-a

content.raw: I'm on purpose not changing any functionality with this PR. I'm only considering a direct port of existing functionality. Changes to the command line arguments can be made in different pull requests.
content.html: I'm on purpose not changing any functionality with this PR. I'm only considering a direct port of existing functionality. Changes to the command line arguments can be made in different pull requests.

content.raw: Also, please don't make any changes like this until after Blueprint. Ideally feature creep is now now feature retreat.
content.html: Also, please don't make any changes like this until after Blueprint. Ideally feature creep is now now feature retreat.

content.raw: I forgot to mention that hidden in this PR is ERB parsing. This means, you should be able to pass `ign gazebo` an SDF file with ERB embedded and it will automatically parse/convert the file.

maybe because it's a component library that's linked to the main library? and maybe it's not working on mojave because of system integrity protection?
